pastas.Description: Thin strands, often coiled into nests
Narrower version of tagliatelle
Thick, softer, spaghetti-like pasta. Made with whole wheat rather than durum. Sometimes made with duck egg.
pastas.Translation: From bigolaro, the pasta press used to make bigoli

pastas.Description: Thick spaghetti-like pasta with a hole running through the center
pastas.Translation: Hollow straws Translated from Italian: buco, meaning "hole", and Italian: bucato, meaning "pierced".
pastas.Synonyms: Boccolotti, perciatellini, foratini, fidelini bucati, fide bucate, agoni bucati, spilloni bucati

pastas.Description: Type of long macaroni. Often coiled around a twig of local weed.
pastas.Synonyms: Busiati, Subioti, fusarioi, maccheroni bobbesi, busa, ciuffolitti (Abruzzo), gnocchi del ferro

pastas.Description: Very thin spaghetti, often coiled into nests. Capelli d'angelo are slightly thinner.
pastas.Synonyms: Angel Hair, Capelli d'angelo, cabellos de angel, capelvenere, fidelini, fedelini, cappellini, sopracappellini, capellini fini, bassetti, tagliolini a nido, barbine a nido, ramicia, vrimiciddi

pastas.Description: Very thin spaghetti
Similar to a twisted buccato with a cleft running on the side
pastas.Translation: Possibly from the thin iron square used to create the cleft.

pastas.Description: Ribbon of pasta approximately 6.5 millimeters wide. Larger and thicker than tagliatelle
Elongated screw.
pastas.Synonyms: filleda, filateddhi, filatelli, fusilli avellinesi, maccaruni aru ferru, ricci di donna

pastas.Description: Flattened spaghetti
Wide pasta
Square or rectangle sheets of pasta that sometimes have fluted edges (lasagne ricce). The square of pasta is lasagna while the dish is lasagne
pastas.Translation: Possibly from Latin lasanum or Greek lasonon, "Cooking pot", or the Greco-Roman laganum, a flat piece of bread.
pastas.Synonyms: bardele, lasagnoni (Veneto); capellasci (Liguria); sagne (Salento); lagana (Apulia); the fluted version can also be doppio festone, sciabo, sciablo

pastas.Description: Narrower version of Lasagna
Longer version of Lasagna
Very thick, long, hand-pulled pasta.
Thin strands of egg-based pasta. Similar to Capelli d'angelo.
Long rectangular ribbons with ruffled sides.
pastas.Translation: Named in honor of Princess Mafalda of Savoy
pastas.Synonyms: Reginette, frese, tagliatelle nervate, signorine, trinette, ricciarelle, sfresatine, nastri, nastrini

pastas.Description: Similar to perciatelli, but folded over rather than hollowed out
Thick flat ribbons of egg-based dough
"Virtually identical to bucatini"
Flat strands about 1.5cm wide. Thinner sheet than lasagna. Can be white or green.
pastas.Translation: In Savonese dialect the name refers to the ribbons used as ornaments by dressmakers. In Genovese dialect however the word means napkin and refers to the size and shape of the pasta.
pastas.Origin: Liguria, in particular the province of Savona

pastas.Description: Very thick, irregular and long, hand-rolled pasta.
Very thin ribbons cooked in beef broth
pastas.Synonyms: Lisanzedas, a variation; large discs in lasagne-like layers

pastas.Description: Serrated ribbons
pastas.Translation: literally the feminine plural of rustico, meaning 'rustic'

pastas.Description: Long tube formed of twisted ribbon
Short, flat ribbons
A long, thin, cylindrical pasta of Italian origin, made of semolina or flour and water. Spaghettini and spaghettoni are slightly thinner or thicker, respectively.
pastas.Translation: "Little strings". Spaghetti is the plural form of the Italian word spaghetto, which is a diminutive of spago, meaning "thin string" or "twine".
pastas.Synonyms: Fide/fidi, fidelini, ristoranti, vermicelloni, filatelli, vermicelloni giganti

pastas.Description: Square spaghetti, made of egg and flour
pastas.Translation: Named after the guitar-like device used to cut the pasta, which has a wooden frame strung with metal wires, sheets of pasta are pressed down onto the device, and then the wires are "strummed" so the slivers of pasta fall through.

pastas.Description: A slightly thinner version of spaghetti
A slightly thicker version of spaghetti
Similar to shoelaces
pastas.Synonyms: Strozzapreti, long, round, thick; lit. 'priest stranglers' (Romagna)

pastas.Description: Extremely rare pasta, made of thinly pulled and folded dough which is laid in the sun to dry.
Ribbons of egg-based pasta. Generally narrower than fettuccine.
pastas.Translation: From the Italian tagliare, meaning "to cut".
pastas.Synonyms: Tagliarelli, reginelle, fresine, nastri, fettuccelle, fettucce romane, fiadi, tagliolini; tagliatelle smalzade (Trentino); lesagnetes (Veneto); bardele (Lombardia); fettuccine (Lazio); pincinelle (Colonna); tagghiarini (Sicily); taddarini (Sardinia)

pastas.Description: Thinner version of tagliatelle
pastas.Translation: From the Italian tagliare, meaning "to cut".

pastas.Description: Thin ribbon ridged on one side. Slightly thicker than linguine.
Thick ribbon ridged on one side
A traditional pasta round that is thinner than spaghetti.

Long, narrow hose-like tubes larger than mezzani (also called mezzi ziti) or bucatini that are traditionally broken before being put to cook. The addition of the word rigati (e.g. ziti rigati) denotes lines or ridges on the pasta's surface. Ziti candelati are longer, zitoni a bit larger.
pastas.Translation: Bride and bridegroom (ziti is plural) in Sicilian dialect.
pastas.Synonyms: Boccolotti, zitoni, zituane, candele, ziti candelati

pastas.Description: Description
Short tubular, or annular-shaped, pasta sometimes with ridges on the inside or outside.
pastas.Synonyms: Anelloni, anellini, anelletti, anelloni d'Africa (large rings)

pastas.Description: Short, thick twisted shape.
Wide ring-shaped pasta
Flattened bell-shaped pasta with a frilly edge on one end. Torchio are identical but with a smooth edge.
pastas.Translation: Bellflower, gigli are lilies, torchio is a press (usually for olive or grapes, but also pasta).

pastas.Description: Extruded pasta that looks like a chef's hat
Short lengths extruded into a S shape.
Designed by Dan Pashman in 2021 – thick, half-tubed pasta with ruffled sides
Shell pasta coiled into a conical shape
pastas.Translation: Translated as "castle dweller", for the shape of the pasta loosely resembles that of a long, flowing robe.

pastas.Description: Corkscrew-shaped macaroni.
pastas.Synonyms: Cellentani, amori, spirali, tortiglioni, or fusilli rigati.

pastas.Description: Short, solid lengths. Exist in three sizes, usually measured in fingers (one, two or three)
pastas.Synonyms: Cortecce, gnocchetti, manatelli, orecchie di prete, strascinati, truoccoli; capunti, cingule, minuich, rascatelli, zinnezinne (Basilicata); cantaroggini, cavatieddi, cecatelli/cicatelli, cecatidde, mignuicchi, strascenate, tagghjunghele (Apulia and Campania); pincinelle (Marche); cavatielle, 'ncatenate, cazzarille, ciufele (Molise); cavasuneddi, cavatuneddi, gnucchitti, gnocculi (Sicily), pizzicarieddi (Apulia). Pictured is dry capunti, a variety of cavatelli from Apulia.
pastas.Origin: Southern continental Italy (i.e. Campania, Apulia, Molise, Basilicata, Calabria) and Sicily

pastas.Description: Short and wide macaroni. Can be smooth (lisce) or furrowed (rigati).
Hand-rolled, shell-shaped pasta that are smaller than malloreddus.
Seashell-shaped, usually furrowed (rigate)
pastas.Synonyms: Arselle, abissini, coccioline, conchigliette, tofettine, cinesini, margaritine, cinesi rigati, mezzi cocci, margherite rigate, cappettine

pastas.Description: Short, curved, and ruffled
Short narrow tube
Bow tie- or butterfly-shaped
pastas.Synonyms: fiochetti, fiocconi, farfalloni, galla genovese, strichetti (Modena), nocchette (Apulia and Abruzzo)

pastas.Description: Thin rectangles or squares of pasta
pastas.Synonyms: Fazzoletti di seta, mandilli di sea (Ligurian dialect)

pastas.Description: Thick ruffled helices
Grooved cut tubes
Shaped like a flower
Long, thick, corkscrew-shaped pasta that may be solid or hollow.
pastas.Translation: The word fusilli presumably comes from Italian: fuso, meaning "spindle".

pastas.Description: A hollow version of fusilli. Note: different shapes can be attached to this name. Can be long, short or twined (lunghi, corti or gemellati).
pastas.Synonyms: Busiata, maccaruna di casa, pirciati, filati cu lu pirtuso, fusilli col buco.

pastas.Description: Egg pasta in a square shape rolled into a tube
A single S-shaped strand of pasta twisted in a loose spiral.
pastas.Translation: The name derives from the Italian for twins.

pastas.Description: Lobed shells. Not to be confused with gnocchi dumplings.
Elbow maccheroni, furrowed.
Curved ridges
Strands of pasta rolled twice around three fingers to form a ring, and then twisted to look like a rope.
Tubes, either bent or straight
pastas.Translation: From Greek for food made from barley

pastas.Description: Hollow tube-shaped pasta that is slightly smaller than a pencil in thickness
Short ribbons with ruffled sides
Irregular shapes of flat pasta formed from scraps of pasta production.
pastas.Synonyms: Strengozze, malmaritati, blecs; pizzocherini (Valtellina); straciamus/spruzzamusi (Mantua); gasse, martaliai (Liguria); begnamusi/sguazzabarbuz (Emilia-Romagna); strengozze (Marche); sagne 'mpezze (Latium); pizzelle (Apulia); foglie di salice (Piedmont)

pastas.Description: Hand-rolled, shell-shaped pasta with saffron. A machine-extruded version also exists, which typically omits the use of saffron.
pastas.Translation: In Campidanese dialect a malloreddu is a male cow (plur. malloreddus)
pastas.Synonyms: Gnocchetti sardi, caidos, macarones cravaos, maccaronis de orgiu

pastas.Description: Designed by Philippe Starck in 1987 for French pasta maker Panzani, intended to compensate for overcooking.
Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro in 1983 – like a rolling ocean wave in cross-section with internal rugosities, but unsuccessful and no longer produced.
Short curved tube
pastas.Synonyms: Perciatelloni, Mezze Zite, Regine, Scaloppi, Napoletani, Hoernli (wide-spread in Switzerland, in at least 3 sizes)

pastas.Description: About half the length of rigatoni
Short version of penne
Wide short tubes
Short coiled pasta
Large tube pasta often topped with sauce or stuffed with ingredients. May collapse under own weight when cooking.
pastas.Translation: from Napolitan paccharia, "Slaps" with a depreciative -ero to indicate something common. The name has been ascribed to a slapping sound they may make when eaten.
pastas.Synonyms: Maniche di frate, maniche rigate, rigatoni, rigatoncini, bombaroni, tufoli rigati. Moccolotti in Marche and Umbria.

pastas.Description: Made from bread crumbs, eggs, grated Parmesan cheese, lemon, and nutmeg, and cooked in chicken broth.
pastas.Origin: Pesaro e Urbino (northern Marche) and other regions of northern Italy such as Emilia Romagna

pastas.Description: Sheet pasta that is similar in shape to a cinnamon stick

Medium length tubes with ridges, cut diagonally at both ends. They can be either lisce (smooth) or rigate (grooved). Mostaccioli is also sometimes used for Barilla products, pennette have a shorter length and pennoni are wider and thicker.
pastas.Translation: Pens (after a quill pen) or feathers.
pastas.Synonyms: Pennine, mezze pennette lisce, mezze penne, mezzani, pennettine, pennuzze, penne regina, mostaccioli, penne a candela, penne di natale/natalini, penne di ziti/zitoni.

pastas.Description: Curled penne variant, usually grooved.
Slightly longer than cavatelli.
Very similar to Lumaconi but smaller has lines running the length of it
A type of short tagliatelle, a flat ribbon pasta, made with buckwheat flour: the lack of gluten makes them hard to manipulate.
Square with rippled edges
Shaped like radiators, they were created between the First and Second World Wars. They are often used in similar dishes as rotelle or fusilli because their shape works well with thicker sauces.
Hollow cut with cylindrical ridges.
Short wide pasta with a 90-degree twist
Short spiralled pasta
Smaller version of rigatoni
Medium-Large tube with square-cut ends, sometimes slightly curved. Always grooved, and straight or bent depending on extrusion method.
pastas.Synonyms: Bombardoni, cannaroni rigati, cannerozzi rigati, rigatoni romani, trivelli, tuffolini rigati

pastas.Description: Rhombus-shaped ribbons
Wagon wheel-shaped pasta
pastas.Synonyms: Biciclette, ruotine, ruote, rotelline, ruotelline, rotine, rotini

pastas.Description: Short thick ribbons from Abruzzo and Molise. Also called sagne or tagliolini.
Rectangular ribbons with fluted edges
Slightly larger than macaroni with a similar slight bend. Can be smooth (lisce) or furrowed (rigati).
pastas.Synonyms: Sedanini, cornetti, diavoletti, diavolini, folletti; or zanne d'elefante if smooth.

pastas.Description: Spiraled tubes
Tightly coiled spirali
Strips of pasta ripped from a sheet.
Rolled across their width. Similar to Sicilian casarecce.
pastas.Synonyms: Strangolarpreti, gnocchi di prete (Friuli); frigulelli, piccicasanti, strozzafrati (Marche), cecamariti (Lazio); maccheroni alla molinara (Abruzzo); strangulaprievete (Naples); strangulaprieviti (Calabria); affogaparini (Sicily)

pastas.Description: Larger tubes than rigatoni, the grooves are also deeper and spiral around the pasta.
Coiled pasta.
Penne shaped as a triangle
Thin twisted pasta made of durum wheat and water. Trofie bastarde are made with chestnut flour.
pastas.Translation: possibly from Greek trophe, "food" or local Genovese dialect strofissià or strufuggiâ, "to rub".

pastas.Description: Pasta in the shape of spinning tops
Ridged rigatoni
Corkscrew-shaped pasta.
Description
Petal shaped, slightly curved with rough convex side
Flat figure-eight stamped from Liguria
pastas.Translation: The name derives from a 14th century Genovese coin, the corzetto.

pastas.Description: Flat strascinato that vaguely resembles carob.
pastas.Translation: Fainella means carob in Pugliese dialect.

pastas.Description: Shaped like an olive leaf
Irregular disc with a central dome and a slightly thicker crown. Strascinate are identical but flat.
pastas.Synonyms: strascinate; recchini (Rome); recchietele (Campania, Molise and Basilicata); orecchie di prete (Abruzzo and Basilicata); cicatelli (Apulia); recchie di prevete (Foggia); cagghiubbi/fenescecchie (Bari); chancierelle/pochiacche (small/big versions; Taranto); stacchiodde (Lecce)

pastas.Description: Description
Bead-like pasta
Pasta that has been mechanically cut or pressed into the letters of the alphabet
Small beads
Small rings of pasta (not to be confused with Calamaretti)
Smaller version of anelli
Small "squiggles"
Small shell-shaped pasta
Semicircular
Ridged tubes
Small short tubes of pasta
Minuscule dots reminding of couscous
pastas.Origin: Liguria, but found throughout Italy and in Malta.

pastas.Description: Short tubes whose diameter is roughly the same as their length. Can be lisci or rigati
pastas.Synonyms: Ditalini, tubetti, tubettini, gnocchetti di ziti, ditaletti, coralli; denti di vecchia, denti di cavallo, ganghi di vecchia, magghietti (Apulia and Sicily)

pastas.Description: Small bow tie-shaped pasta
pastas.Translation: Little butterflies ("bow tie" in Italian is cravatta a farfalla, "butterfly tie")

pastas.Description: Pasta prepared with eggs, flour and water.
Smaller version of fideos, about 12–15 mm long before cooking
Bead-like pasta from Sardinia. Slightly toasted due to drying process.
Small mushroom-shaped pasta
Farm animals
Grain-shaped
Short curled lengths of pasta. Spaccatelle are larger.
pastas.Synonyms: Crestine, margherite lisce, fagioletti, zitellini, tubettini lunghi, gramignoni, spaccatelle

pastas.Description: Small granular, irregular shaped pasta (smaller version then Grattoni)
Large granular, irregular shaped pasta
Daisy-shaped
Lace-shaped
Flat teardrop shaped pasta (similar to Orzo but wider)
Thick rings
Very small rings of pasta
Rice shaped pasta. Risoni are slightly bigger.
pastas.Synonyms: Puntine, punte d'ago, armelline, semi d'orzo, semi d'avena, semi di riso, occhi di giudeo, armellette, puntalette, semi di cicoria, cicorietta, risetto, chicchi di riso, semini, avena, avena grande, cicorie, semi di melone, semi di mela, midolline, semoni, risone, risoni riso

pastas.Description: Although pastina is the name for an entire family of miniature pasta shapes, it is also used to describe the most basic one in this family – small spheres, smaller than acini di pepe
Spheres slightly larger than acini di pepe
Rice grains, spheres or other forms
pastas.Synonyms: Israeli couscous, Jerusalem couscous, giant couscous, pearl couscous

pastas.Description: Smaller version of Risi
Small flat squares of pasta
pastas.Synonyms: Quadrucci, quadratini, quadretti, lucciole, quadrellini, quadrotti; quaternei (Emilia-Romagna); squadrucchetti (Umbria); ciciarchiola/cicerchiole (depending on size; Lazio).

pastas.Description: Small bell shaped pasta with a ruffled edge and a crease on one side. Can be ridged or smooth (lisce)
Small star-shaped pasta.
pastas.Translation: Stars, small or big (resp. stelline or stellette)
pastas.Synonyms: anellini, avermarie, astri, fiori di sambuco, lentine, puntine, semini, stellettine, stellette

pastas.Description: Smaller version of elbow macaroni
In larger varieties these are sometimes called farfalle tonde. Small bow tie-shaped pasta with rounded edges.
pastas.Synonyms: Signorine, canestri, canestrini, farfallini, galani, nastrini, nodini, stricchetti

pastas.Description: Description
Agnolini are a type of stuffed egg pasta originating from the province of Mantua (in the Mantuan dialect they are commonly called "agnulìn" or "agnulì") and are oftentimes eaten in soup or broth.'
Semicircular or square pockets; can be stuffed with ricotta, a mix of cheese and meats (agnolotti di grasso), or pureed vegetables (agnolotti di magro).
pastas.Translation: Diminutive of old word for "angel"; Agnolotti was Giotto di Bondone's nickname.
pastas.Synonyms: agnellotti, agnolòt, angelotti, langaroli, langheroli, piat d'angelòt

pastas.Description: Large bowl-like pasta intended for stuffing
Rolls of pasta with various fillings, usually cooked in an oven
pastas.Synonyms: Cannaciotti, canneroncini, cannarone/cannerone (Naples), cannarune (Apulia), canneroni, cannoli/ crusetti (Sicily), manfriguli/manfrigoli (Valtellina), manicotti (in the US), gnocchettoni zitoni, tagliati di zitoni, cannelloni zitoni, spole, sigarette, schiaffoni

pastas.Description: Squares of dough filled with cheese (or, rarely, meat) and closed to form a small hat (cappello=hat). In the large majority of Romagna the filling is made with a mixture of parmesan and soft cheese.
pastas.Synonyms: cappelli, cappelli del prete, or nicci in Tuscany.

pastas.Description: A stuffed pasta resembling double twist candies.
A stuffed pasta with various fillings.
A stuffed pasta with various fillings
Large, stuffable seashell shaped
A stuffed pasta typical with a filling of potato and mint
A 'purse' or bundle of pasta, made from a round of dough gathered into a ball-shaped bundle, often stuffed with ricotta and fresh pear
Snailshell-shaped pieces. Larger than gomiti or pipe.
pastas.Synonyms: Lumachelle, lumachette, cirillini, chifferini, ciocchiolette, cirillini, gomitini, gozziti, lumachelle, lumachoni, pipe, pipette, tofarelle

pastas.Description: Semicircular pockets about 2.5 in. diameter
Large, stuffed, penne-shaped pasta. Around 1.5 inches long.
Triangular shape with a bulging center, does not contain meat.

Two pieces of pasta on top of another, stuffed with cheese, ground meat, pureed vegetables, or mixtures thereof. Though commonly square, other forms are also used, including circular and semi-circular (Mezzelune)
pastas.Translation: Many claimed origins: possibly from rapa, "vegetable root", or rabibole, "cheap stuff" in Ligurian dialect; or simply from ravolgere, "to wrap".

pastas.Description: A rolled pasta with filling; cooked roll is normally sliced, covered in sauce and broiled in the oven
pastas.Synonyms: Rotoli imbotito; strudel (Trentino-Alto Adige); pasta al sacco (Marche)

pastas.Description: Round, similar to fagottini, but also may use ravioli stuffing. A small square of pasta brought around the stuffing and twisted.

Square sheet of pasta folded into a triangle or discus folded into half-circle, with both extremities subsequently joined to form a ring shape. About 30x35 mm in size. Sweet variations can be found (tortelli cremaschi).
pastas.Synonyms: Cappellacci, turtello (Emilia-Romagna), tordelli (Tuscany), casonsei (Bergame and Brescia)

pastas.Description: Ring-shaped, usually stuffed with a mixture of meat and cheese. About 25x20mm in size.
Round or rectangular, similar to tortelli but larger (38x45mm). Stuffing usually does not include meat.
A pasta shell large enough for stuffing (as with meat or cheese). From a southern Italian dialect, plural of tufolo (tube), modification of Latin tubulus (tubule)
pastas.Synonyms: Maniche, Gigantoni, Occhi di elefante, Elefante, Canneroni grandi, Occhi di bove

pastas.Description: Description
Small balls of dough. Usually made of bread crumbs, but sweet variants would have a potato base.
Elongated, narrow dumpling
pastas.Origin: Piedmont, more particularly Cuneo province and Valle Colla.

pastas.Description: various thick, small, and soft dough dumplings
pastas.Translation: May be derived from the Italian word nocchio, meaning a knot in wood, or from nocca, meaning knuckle
pastas.Synonyms: Gnocchetti, gnocchi alla romana, gnudi, malfatti, strangulaprievete, cavatelli, malloreddus
